Between the private law of Rome as stated by Gaius, and as stated by Justinian, there is far more difference in the matter of personae and actiones than in the intermediate department, the ‘ius quod ad res pertinet: except perhaps in such part of the latter as relates to inherit· auce or succession. The most important points of change in the subject now under our immediate consideration are briefly as follows: (ι) The threefold division of libertini into cives, Latini, and dediticii, which was important when Gaius wrote, was practically obsolete in the time of justinian, who formally abolished it; this necessitate-d a change in the law os manumission, which was greatly simplified‚ the statutes which had introduced these distinctions being to that extent repealed, as also was the lex Fufia Caninia, limiting the number of slaves who could be manumitted by testament3 (a) of persons ‘ alieno iuri subiectae,’ exclusive of slaveS, there had in Gaius’ time been three classes, viz. those in paternal power, those in manu, and those in mancipio. In the Institutes patria potestas is still a living reality, but manus and mancipium have become obsolete ; hence a second simplifioetion, the modes in which manus could arise, and some os the purposes sor which it had been employed, being a somewhat compli- oeted and difficult branch of law. (3) In Justinian legitimation of chil- dren not under patria potestas at birth is definitely treated as one of the modes in which this power may originate; in Gaius' time this occurred only by the fact of a Latinus acquiring the civitas, and by his children born before this event being subjected to his potestas; but in the later period there were no Latini; and accordingly the long discussion in Gaius (i. 65-96) ‘ de statu liberorum‚' and on the modes in which a Latin could become a civis, has no counterpart in Justinian except the paragraph on legitimation in i. 10. 133 (4) with regard to adop- tion sensu stricto, Justinian completely altered its form, and also its effect unless the adopting person was a natural ascendant3 with regard to ‘ adrogati0‚' the form had been changed between the two writerS, it being now effected ‘ principali rescript0,’ not ‘ populi auctoritate? as in the time os Gaius ; but no other change of any great importance had been made in this branch of law. (5) Justinian entirely changed the mode of emancipation (i. 12. 6.) by substituting for the old fictitious sale a mere declaration by the parent before a magistrate. (6) In the department of guardianship the ‘ perpetua mulierum tutela,' with which, though still existing in his day, Gaius (i. 190) had expressed his dissatisfaction, had altogether disappeared long before the compilation os the Corpus Iuris.
